info.title: Migration Toolkit for Virtualization
info.subtitle: Migrating from VMware to Red Hat OpenShift Virtualization

abstract.para: This guide describes how to use the Migration Toolkit for Virtualization to migrate VMware virtual machines to Red Hat OpenShift Virtualization.

preface.title: Preface
preface.simpara: Migration Toolkit for Virtualization (MTV) enables you to migrate a large number of virtual machines from VMware vSphere to OpenShift Virtualization.
You can download the VMware provider data collected by MTV and upload it to the Migration Analytics service on cloud.redhat.com for a detailed workload analysis report and migration recommendations.

chapter.title: About Migration Toolkit for Virtualization
chapter.simpara: MTV creates the following custom resources (CRs):

listitem.simpara: Provider:
Created when you add a source or target provider
Stores provider attributes in order to connect to and interact with the providers
Plan:
Created when you create a migration plan
Contains a list of VMs that are migrated together with the same migration parameters
Selects VMs to fit the available migration resources until all VMs are migrated
Mapping: Created when you map source and target networks or source and target storage
Migration:
Created when you run a migration plan
Aggregates the migration progress
If a virtual machine fails to migrate, you can run a new migration with the same migration plan. Only the virtual machines that have not migrated will be migrated.
Provider Inventory:
Connects to the source and target providers
Maintains a local inventory for mappings and plans
Separate provider inventory pods for each provider enable scalability
Validation:
Validates the suitability of a VM for migration to OpenShift Virtualization by applying rules
Triggered by the Provider Inventory service whenever a VM configuration change is detected
Stores the VM validation status
User Interface:
Enables you to manipulate the MTV CRs
Indicates the state of the CRs
Displays the progress of a migration
Controller: Implements the logic to reconcile the CRs with the state defined by the user
For example, when you create a Plan, the controllers validate it and add a status label. If a Plan fails validation, its status is Not ready and the Plan cannot be used to perform a migration.
Aggregates the status of related CRs to provide a holistic and consistent view of the state of a migration

chapter.title: Installing Migration Toolkit for Virtualization
chapter.simpara: You can install the Migration Toolkit for Virtualization (MTV) by using the OpenShift Virtualization web console or the CLI.
Then you can create a VMware Virtual Disk Development Kit (VDDK) image. MTV uses VDDK to copy the source disks.

section.title: Installing MTV with the web console
section.simpara: You can install the Migration Toolkit for Virtualization (MTV) by using the OpenShift Virtualization web console.

listitem.simpara: Admin privileges
In the OpenShift Virtualization web console, click Operators → OperatorHub.
Use the Filter by keyword field to find the MTV Operator.
Select the MTV Operator and click Install.
On the Install Operator page, click Install.
On the Installed Operators page, the MTV Operator appears in the openshift-migration project with the status Succeeded.
Click MTV Operator.
Under Provided APIs, locate the VirtController tile, and click Create Instance.
Click Create.
Click Workloads → Pods to verify that the Provider Inventory, Validation, User Interface, and Controller pods are running.

section.title: Installing MTV from the CLI
section.simpara: You can install the Migration Toolkit for Virtualization from the CLI.

listitem.simpara: OpenShift CLI installed
Admin privileges
Log in to the Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform cluster and create an openshift-migration project:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat << EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: project.openshift.io/v1 kind: Project metadata: name: openshift-migration EOF

listitem.simpara: Create an OperatorGroup object called migration:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat << EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1 kind: OperatorGroup metadata: name: migration namespace: openshift-migration spec: targetNamespaces: - openshift-migration EOF

listitem.simpara: Create a Subscription object for the virt-operator:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat << EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1alpha1 kind: Subscription metadata: name: virt-operator namespace: openshift-migration spec: channel: development installPlanApproval: Automatic name: virt-operator source: konveyor-for-vms sourceNamespace: openshift-marketplace startingCSV: "konveyor-virt-operator.v99.0.0" EOF

listitem.simpara: Create a VirtController object:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat << EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: virt.konveyor.io/v1alpha1 kind: VirtController metadata: name: virt-controller namespace: openshift-migration spec: olm_managed: true EOF

listitem.simpara: View the resources created by the VirtController object:

section.title: Adding a VDDK image to MTV
section.simpara: You can create a VDDK image and store it in a private image registry. Then, you can add the image to the v2v-vmware ConfigMap.

note.simpara: Storing the VDDK image in a public registry might violate the terms of the VMware license.

listitem.simpara: An internal Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform image registry or a secure external registry
Access to the image registry from your OpenShift Virtualization environment
Podman installed
Create and navigate to a temporary directory:
In a browser, navigate to VMware code and click SDKs.
In the Compute Virtualization section, click Virtual Disk Development Kit (VDDK).
Select the VDDK version that corresponds to your VMware vSphere version, for example, VDDK 7.0 for vSphere 7.0.
Click Download and save the VDDK archive in the temporary directory.
Extract the VDDK archive:
Create a Dockerfile:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat > Dockerfile <<EOF FROM busybox:latest COPY vmware-vix-disklib-distrib /vmware-vix-disklib-distrib RUN mkdir -p /opt ENTRYPOINT ["cp", "-r", "/vmware-vix-disklib-distrib", "/opt"] EOF

listitem.simpara: Build the image:
For an internal Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform registry, specify the internal registry route, for example, image-registry.openshift-image-registry.svc:5000/openshift/vddk:<tag>.
For an external registry, specify the server name, path, and tag, for example, server.example.com:5000/vddk:<tag>.
Push the image to the registry:
Edit the v2v-vmware ConfigMap in the openshift-cnv project:
Add the vddk-init-image parameter to the data stanza:

section.title: Migrating virtual machines with the web console
section.simpara: You can add providers, create network and storage mappings, and create and run a migration plan in the web console.

listitem.simpara: In the web console, navigate to Providers and click Add provider.
Click Check connection to verify the credentials.
Click Add to add and save the provider.
The provider appears in the list of providers.

section.title: Adding a VMware provider
section.simpara: You can add a VMware provider in the web console.

listitem.simpara: Admin privileges
In the web console, navigate to Providers and click Add provider.
Select VMware from the Type list.
Fill in the following fields:
Name: vCenter name to display in the list of providers
Hostname: vCenter host name or IP address
Username: vCenter admin user name, for example, administrator@vsphere.local
Password: vCenter password
Click Check connection to verify the credentials.
Click Add to add and save the provider.
The provider appears in the list of providers.

section.title: Creating mappings
section.simpara: You must create mappings to map the source and target networks and storage.

listitem.simpara: Click Create mapping.
Click Create.
Click Create mapping.
Click Create.

section.title: Creating a migration plan
section.simpara: You can create a migration plan in the web console.

A migration plan allows you to group virtual machines that should be migrated together or with the same migration parameters, for example, a percentage of the members of a cluster or a complete application.

listitem.simpara: The migration network supports migration.
The web console has source and target providers.
In the web console, navigate to Migration plans and click Create migration plan.
Fill in the following fields in the General settings screen:
Plan name: Plan name that is displayed in the web console.
Plan description: Optional. Brief description of the migration plan.
Source provider: Select a VMware provider.
Target provider: Select an OpenShift Virtualization provider.
Click Next.
Filter the VMs that you want to migrate by selecting data centers, clusters, or folders.
Select the VMs to migrate. You can click each VM to view its migration risk assessment.
Select an existing storage mapping or create a new storage mapping.
If you want to create a new storage mapping:
Select a data store from the Source datastores list and a storage class from the Target storage classes list.
Click Add to create additional storage mappings or to map multiple data stores to a single storage class.
Click Next.
Select an existing network mapping or create a new network mapping.
If you want to create a new network mapping:
Select a network from the Source networks list and a network from the Target networks list.
Click Add to create additional network mappings or to map multiple source networks to a single target network.
Click Next.
Review your migration plan and click Finish.
The migration plan is saved in the migration plan list.

section.title: Running a migration plan
section.simpara: You can run a migration plan and view its progress in the web console.

listitem.simpara: The VMware VMs must be powered off.
In the web console, navigate to Migration plans.
The Migration plans list displays the source and target providers, the number of VMs being migrated, the status of the plan, and a high-level progress bar that shows how many VMs have been migrated.
Click Start beside a migration plan with a Ready status to run the plan.
To view the Migration Details by VM screen, click the name of a migration plan.
This screen displays the migration start and end time, the amount of data copied, and a progress pipeline for each VM being migrated.
Expand a VM to view the migration steps, elapsed time of each step, and the state.

section.title: Migrating virtual machines from the CLI
section.simpara: You can migrate virtual machines from the command line (CLI) by creating the following custom resources:

listitem.simpara: Secret: Contains the VMware vSphere credentials
Provider: Specifies the VMware provider
Plan: Specifies the source and target clusters, network mappings, data store mappings, and VMs to migrate
Migration: Runs the Plan
If a Migration does not complete, you can create a new Migration CR, referencing the same Plan, to migrate the remaining VMs.
OpenShift CLI installed
Admin privileges
Get the SSL thumbprint of the vCenter:
Create a Secret object with the VMware credentials:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat < EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: v1 kind: Secret metadata: name: vmware-secret namespace: openshift-migration type: Opaque stringData: user: administrator@vsphere.local password: <password> thumbprint: <01:23:45:67:89:AB:CD:EF:01:23:45:67:89:AB:CD:EF:01:23:45:67> EOF

listitem.simpara: Create a Provider object for VMware vSphere:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat < EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: virt.konveyor.io/v1alpha1 kind: Provider metadata: name: vmware-provider namespace: openshift-migration spec: type: vsphere url: https://<vcenter.example.com>/sdk secret: name: vmware-secret namespace: openshift-migration EOF

callout.para: Specify the vSphere API end point.

listitem.simpara: Create a Plan object for the migration:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat < EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: virt.konveyor.io/v1alpha1 kind: Plan metadata: name: test-migration-plan namespace: openshift-migration spec: provider: source: name: vmware-provider namespace: openshift-migration destination: name: host namespace: openshift-migration map: networks: - source: id: <network-31> destination: type: pod name: pod namespace: openshift-migration - source: id: <network-723> destination: type: pod name: pod namespace: openshift-migration datastores: - source: id: <datastore-30> destination: storageClass: standard - source: id: <datastore-35> destination: storageClass: standard vms: - id: <vm-1630> - id: <vm-2841> EOF

callout.para: The OpenShift provider is added automatically as host when the Operator is deployed.
Specify the IDs of the VMs to migrate.

listitem.simpara: Create a Migration CR to run the Plan CR:
listitem.programlisting: $ cat < EOF | oc apply -f - --- apiVersion: virt.konveyor.io/v1alpha1 kind: Migration metadata: name: migration-test-001 namespace: openshift-migration spec: plan: name: test-migration-plan namespace: openshift-migration EOF

section.simpara: The Migration CR creates a VirtualMachineImport object for each VM being migrated. You can monitor the progress of the migration by viewing the VirtualMachineImport pods in the openshift-migration namespace.

chapter.title: Using Migration Analytics
chapter.simpara: You can use the Migration Analytics service at cloud.redhat.com to analyze your VMware workloads and to provide migration recommendations.
Migration Analytics generates a report that you can view in your browser or download as a CSV file.

section.title: About the Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: The Migration Analytics report contains a VM migration summary and a VM migration inventory.

formalpara.title: VM migration summary
formalpara.para: The VM migration summary displays the following information:

listitem.simpara: Summary: Providers, hosts, clusters, and VMs. Percentage of VMs that have no issues for migrating to OpenShift Virtualization.
Migration risk assessment: Suitability of a VM for migration. The assessment is determined by rules that detect certain configurations or operating systems.
Rules summary (issues that impact migration risk): Information about the rules.
Operating systems identified: Operating systems that can be migrated to Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

formalpara.title: VM migration inventory
formalpara.para: The VM migration inventory displays a list of virtual machines with detailed information.

section.simpara: You can click a VM to view its migration risk assessment.
You can filter the VM migration inventory and export it as a CSV file.

section.title: Creating a Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: You can download VMware provider data in the MTV web console and upload it to the Migration Analytics service on cloud.redhat.com to create a Migration Analytics report.

listitem.simpara: In the web console, navigate to Providers.
In the VMware tab, select a VMware provider and click Download data.
Launch a browser and navigate to cloud.redhat.com.
In the Migration Services tile, click Migration Analytics.
Click Get Started if you are creating a report for the first time or navigate to Payload Files and click Upload file.
Browse to the VMware provider data file and click Open.
Select the data file and click Create report.
Select OpenShift Virtualization as the Preferred target.
Enter the Report name and optional Report description.
Click OK.
The generated report appears in the Reports list.

section.simpara: You can filter the results of a Migration Analytics report to display virtual machines according to provider, cluster, migration effort, and other parameters.

listitem.simpara: Click VM migration inventory in the Migration Analytics report.
Click Filter and select a filter type, for example, Provider, OS type, or Rules.
Click Filter by <filter_type> and select one or more options.
If you are filtering by VM name, enter the text in the search field.
The filtered virtual machines are displayed.

section.simpara: You can export a complete or filtered Migration Analytics report in CSV format.

listitem.simpara: Click VM migration inventory in the Migration Analytics report.
Optional: Filter the report.
Click Export as CSV.
The Migration Analytics report is downloaded to your local machine as a CSV file.

section.simpara: TBD

section.title: Known issues - in progress
section.simpara: This section describes known issues and steps to resolve them.

section.title: Unsupported VMware features
section.simpara: The following VMware features are not supported by OpenShift Virtualization:

listitem.simpara: VMware Site Recovery Manager (SRM). You can migrate the VM but SRM will not be enabled.
vSphere Distributed Power Management (DPM). You can migrate the VM but DPM will not be enabled.
VMDK with SCSI-3 persistent reservation (PR). You can migrate the VM but SCSI-3 PR will not be enabled. NEED INFO
